author: Sergi Peralta Moreno
title: Cisma en el comit\u00e9 de empresa de Reus Net: las negociaciones del convenio laboral, en punto muerto
text:
Laboral
Cisma en el comité de empresa de Reus Net: las negociaciones del convenio laboral, en punto muerto
Los sindicatos no han ratificado el principio de acuerdo y la cuestión podría acabar en los tribunales
Cuando parecía que el final del conflicto se avistaba en el horizonte, un cisma interno ha dividido a los trabajadores y ha alejado posiciones. El comité de empresa y la dirección de Reus Net —la unión temporal (UTE) formada por Valoriza Servicios Medioambientales y Romero Polo, adjudicataria del servicio de limpieza viaria y recogida de residuos— llegaron, la noche del 14 al 15 de noviembre, a un principio de acuerdo para tener un nuevo convenio laboral.
Estaba previsto que el documento se formalizara el pasado martes, 26 de noviembre, sin embargo, según ha podido saber Diari Més, la firma continúa en el aire —ni UGT, ni CCOO, ni USO lo han ratificado— y el asunto podría acabar en los tribunales. El preacuerdo se alcanzó con un asterisco. Fuentes de Comisiones Obreras declaran que lo firmaron «coaccionados», ya que, si no, no recibirían la documentación.
Dejaron claro, además, que querían consultar las condiciones con sus afiliados antes de dar luz verde al texto. Con una asamblea, a la cual también asistieron simpatizantes, se llegó a la conclusión «que más de la mitad de la plantilla no está conforme con el preacuerdo».
«Al final, salió mayoritaria la negativa a firmar el convenio», aseguran fuentes de CCOO, que añaden que la representación de UGT, sindicato mayoritario, «se levantó de la mesa y no quiso firmarlo», supuestamente, «al enterarse de que, si lo firmaban, tendrían más de la mitad de la plantilla en contra». Fuentes de UGT consultadas por Diari Més informan de que están en un proceso «de asambleas internas, de información y aceptación», y que, por ahora, no ofrecerán «declaraciones» al respecto.
Desde CCOO, se detalla que se ha convocado una mediación con el Tribunal Laboral de Cataluña (TLC) para la próxima semana para «llegar a un acuerdo». «Si no se llegara, el asunto podría acabar en los tribunales», apuntan, teniendo en cuenta que, en principio, la empresa adjudicataria del servicio «habría cerrado la mesa negociadora». Este medio se ha puesto en contacto con la UTE, pero, al cierre de la presente edición, no ha obtenido respuesta sobre la cuestión.
Antigüedad y un tope
El principio de acuerdo del nuevo convenio laboral contemplaba incrementos salariales «igual que los funcionarios públicos» y una serie de mejoras encaminadas a facilitar la conciliación familiar, como la posibilidad de disfrutar «de más sábados de fiesta», tal como explicó el presidente del comité de empresa, Miguel Pérez.
CCOO menciona que las propuestas se pueden mejorar. Uno de los principales puntos de desacuerdo es el hecho de que las subidas del sueldo estarían limitadas a un 2,5%. «Si suben las retribuciones a los funcionarios un 3%, nosotros sólo tendríamos un aumento del 2,5%», señalan las fuentes. Además, las mejoras no se verían aplicadas en las nóminas del 2024, ejercicio que se olvidaría y «se taparía» con 800 euros.
El otro aspecto que ha causado fricción es el hecho de «que nos congelan la antigüedad», es decir, que se dejarían de contabilizar los años que se trabajen en la empresa. No se sacarían los pluses actuales, «pero no generarás más antigüedad». «La antigüedad es sagrada, innegociable», asevera el sindicato. Según declara, la compañía les habría ofrecido bonificaciones al cumplir diez años de trabajo y, después, cada cinco años más.
Asimismo, las fuentes comentan que la plantilla «no está de acuerdo» con la propuesta de que, los sábados que les toque trabajar, puedan acabar 45 minutos antes, ya que les parece insuficiente. Añaden «que el Gobierno aprobará la reducción de la jornada laboral, y en ningún momento eso queda reflejado». Está previsto que el nuevo convenio de Reus Net esté vigente hasta el 31 de diciembre del 2028. Mientras no se acuerde, se apruebe y entre en vigor, se sigue aplicando el convenio anterior, firmado en el 2022 y que caducó en junio del 2024.
Después de dos días de calma, vuelve la tormenta al servicio de limpieza
En paralelo, hace pocos días, el Tribunal Supremo decidió no admitir el recurso de casación presentado por FCC Medi Ambient SA contra la adjudicación del contrato del servicio de limpieza viaria, una resolución que ponía punto final al recorrido judicial de las reclamaciones de la empresa.

author: Contributor
title: Aliyev Says No Peace Without Changes in Armenia’s Constitution – Asbarez.com
text: YEREVAN (Azatutyun.am)—Armenia must change its constitution in order to make peace with Azerbaijan, Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev said on Thursday, stoking Armenian opposition claims that Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan has already agreed to make such a concession to Baku. “In case of changing Armenia’s constitution and other documents, peace could be achieved,” Aliyev said. “Armenia’s Declaration of Independence contains direct call for uniting Azerbaijan’s Karabakh region to Armenia and infringing on Azerbaijan’s territorial integrity. Armenia’s constitution cites that document.” Pashinyan stated on January 18 that Armenia must adopt a new constitution reflecting the “new geopolitical environment” in the region. Critics believe he first and foremost wants to get rid of the current constitution’s preamble that makes reference to the declaration cited by Aliyev. The declaration adopted in 1990 in turn cites a 1989 unification act by the legislative bodies of Soviet Armenia and the then Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast. It also calls for international recognition of the 1915 genocide of Armenians “in Ottoman Turkey and Western Armenia.” Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan acknowledged last week that Azerbaijan has objected to this constitutional introduction during talks on a peace treaty with Armenia. But both he and Pashinyan allies claimed that the Armenian leadership is not seeking to change the constitution because of that. Armenian opposition leaders portrayed Aliyev’s latest statement as further proof of their claims that Pashinyan is planning to enact a new constitution at the behest of Baku as well as Ankara. One of them, Artsvik Minasyan, said the two Turkic allies want to force the Armenians to “renounce their historical past and rights.” “If you do what your enemy wants, it means you obey its rules of the game,” Minasyan told RFE/RL’s Armenian Service. Vladimir Vartanian, a senior pro-government lawmaker, stuck to the official line that Pashinyan’s administration is not forced to embark on the constitutional reform. “No constitution can be adopted under pressure because if we adopt a constitution under pressure it means that we have a problem with our sovereignty,” he said. Pashinyan called for the new constitution just days after complaining that Aliyev has toughened its position on the Armenian-Armenian peace treaty and openly laid claim to Armenian territory. He went on to offer more security “guarantees” to Baku. Pashinyan’s political opponents say this appeasement policy will not lead to a lasting peace between the two South Caucasus nations.

title: Want To Get Into Stargazing? A Professional Astronomer Explains Where To Start | MENAFN.COM
text:
Author: Jonti Horner ( MENAFN - The Conversation) There are few things more peaceful and relaxing than a night under the stars. Through the holidays, many people head away from the bright city lights to go camping. They revel in the dark skies, spangled with myriad stars.
As a child, I loved such trips, and they helped cement my passion for the night sky, and for all things space.
One of my great joys as an astronomer is sharing the night sky with people. There is something wondrous about helping people stare at the cosmos through a telescope, getting their first glimpses of the universe's many wonders. But we can also share and enjoy the night sky just with our own eyes – pointing out the constellations and the planets, or discovering the joys of watching meteor showers .
It is easy to be bitten by the astronomy bug, and a common question I get asked is“how can I get more into stargazing?”. Here are ways to get started in this fascinating and timeless hobby that won't break the bank.
Learning the night sky A good place to start if you're a budding astronomer is to learn your way around the night sky. When I was young, this involved getting hold of a planisphere (a star map, you can make your own here ), or a good reference book .
Today, there are countless good apps to help you find your way around the night sky.
A great example of such an app is Stellarium – a planetarium program allowing you to view the night sky from the comfort of your room or to plan an evening's observing ahead of schedule.
To memorise the night sky, you can try star hopping. Pick out a bright, famous, easy to find constellation, and use it as a guide to help you identify the constellations around it.
Learn one constellation per week, and within a year, you'll be familiar with most of the constellations visible from your location.
Let's use Orion as an example. The slider below shows images from Stellarium, with Orion riding high in the sky on a summer's evening. I've added arrows to show how you can use Orion (shown in the centre of the map below) to hop around the summer sky.
To learn the constellations around Orion, your task is relatively straightforward. Head out on a clear, dark summer's night, and find Orion high to the north. The three stars of Orion's belt are a fantastic signpost to Orion's neighbours.
If you follow the line of the belt upwards and to the right, you come to Sirius – the brightest star in the night sky, and the brightest star in Canis Major , the big hunting dog. Carry the line on and curve to the left as you go, and you'll find Canopus , the second brightest star in the sky.
Now come back to Orion's belt, and follow its line down and to the left. You'll come to a V-shaped group of stars, including the bright red Aldebaran . This is the Hyades star cluster (with Aldebaran a foreground interloper), which makes up the head of Taurus , the bull.
Take the line further, and you come to the Pleiades – often known as the Seven Sisters – a beautiful star cluster easily visible to the naked eye.
Back to Orion again. This time, you're going to draw a line from Rigel (the bright star at the top-left of Orion's boxy body) through Betelgeuse (the bright red star at the lower-right of the box) and continue it towards the horizon. This takes you to Gemini – the twins.
Just by using Orion as the signpost, you can find your way to a good number of constellations (the cyan line points to Lepus , the hare; the white line to Canis Minor , the little hunting dog).
By star hopping, you'll slowly but surely learn your way around the night sky until the constellations become familiar friends.
Read more: Kindred skies: ancient Greeks and Aboriginal Australians saw constellations in common
Virtual observing Looking at the sky with the naked eye is a wonderful thing, but it's also great to zoom in and see more detail.
What if you don't have access to binoculars or a telescope of your own? Thankfully, software like Stellarium can give you a fantastic virtual observing experience.
Imagine you want to see Saturn's rings – a spectacular sight through even a small telescope. You can easily do this with Stellarium. Find Saturn by using the search bar and click on it to bring up the planet's info.
Click on the cross-hair symbol to“lock on”, then zoom in. The further you zoom in, the more you'll see. You can even run the clock forwards or backwards to see the planet's moons move in their orbits, or the tilt of Saturn's rings changing from our viewpoint over time .
A virtual observing session is as simple as that – just pan around the sky until you find something you want to see, and zoom in.
Example of using the clock feature in Stellarium to see the movement of Saturn's moons. Stellarium A hobby best shared Now, a virtual observing session is great, but it pales compared to the real thing. I'd recommend using planetarium programs like Stellarium to figure out what you want to see, then heading out to look at it with your own eyes.
Astronomy is a wonderful hobby, and one that is best shared. Most towns and cities have their own astronomy clubs, and they're usually more than happy to welcome guests who want to gaze at the night sky.
I joined my local astronomy society, the West Yorkshire Astronomical Society in the United Kingdom, when I was just eight years old. I owe them so much. The members were incredibly supportive of a young kid with so many questions, and I genuinely believe I would not be where I am today without their help. As a member, I saw firsthand just how fantastic the amateur astronomy community is.
The author Jonti Horner at age 16, showing then Astronomer Royal of the UK, Arnold Wolfendale (right), the WYAS 18-inch telescope, hand-made by members. Also seen is the society's then president, Ken Willoughby. Alan Horner, author provided At the society, we had weekly talks on astronomy, given by the club members and visiting astronomers from local universities. We also had regular night sky viewing nights, using the society's very own telescope – a behemoth the members had built themselves.
People who are passionate about their hobby love nothing more than sharing it with others. The members of astronomical societies are fantastic guides to the night sky, and they often have incredible equipment they're more than happy to share with you.
Both astronomy clubs and universities often offer public night sky viewing nights, which are the perfect opportunity to peer at the sky through a telescope, with an experienced guide on hand to find the most impressive sights to share.
So, if you want to learn more about the night sky, reach out to your local astronomy society – it could be the start of something very special.
If you want to find a local astronomy group, check out this list . If you're a member of a group that isn't listed, please reach out to get them to update the list using the 'Contact Us' link.

title: Muchos pequeños aún sufren por los Herodes actuales - Diario de Yucatán
text: Los Santos Inocentes es una fiesta dentro de la octava de Navidad, es decir, los ocho días posteriores al 25 de diciembre, seguida también de las celebraciones en honor de San Esteban Mártir y San Juan Evangelista, recordó el presbítero Jorge Martínez Ruz, vocero de la Arquidiócesis de Yucatán. Los Santos Inocentes son recordados cada 28 de diciembre por ser los niños menores de dos años que murieron cuando el rey Herodes buscaba al Niño Dios para matarlo pensando en que sería un heredero que pudiera quitarle el trono y ordenó matar a todos los niños menores de dos años de edad en Belén. Los niños que mueren a causa de este mandato del rey son los Santos Inocentes que dieron su vida por Jesús sin siquiera conocerlo. Con el paso del tiempo, la Iglesia comenzó a celebrarlos y venerarlos, así como también a aquéllos que han derramado su sangre en nombre de Jesús. Bromas En muchos lugares se tiene la costumbre de hacer bromas o que los medios de comunicación den noticias falsas haciendo referencia a los inocentes que las creen. “Es una costumbre de no muy buen gusto que en muchos lugares de realiza, pero que nada tiene que ver con la costumbre cristiana católica y con el tema de la fe”, opinó el vocero. “Por el lado de la fe, lo que hacemos es celebrar a los mártires que dieron su vida por Jesús, mientras que la costumbre de hacer engaños o bromas va en la línea de burlarse de alguien que presume ser inocente. “En el lado de la fe, la inocencia está en que sin tener culpa han sufrido el martirio, y por el lado de las bromas está en aprovecharse de alguien que es indefenso o que no tiene manera de reconocer la broma”, dijo. Para la Iglesia, continuó, “no consideramos muy respetuoso realizar bromas de mal gusto a personas inocentes; por el contrario, el signo de los inocentes está precisamente en aquéllos que han sufrido por causa de Jesús y hoy hay muchos que son reflejo de esos Santos Inocentes; por ejemplo, los niños maltratados, explotados o que son obligados a trabajar, ellos siguen siendo abusados por parte de los Herodes modernos. “Incluso, también los no nacidos a causa del aborto son un reflejo de estos Santos Inocentes que siguen padeciendo y muriendo no necesariamente por Jesús sino por las injusticias sociales”, señaló el sacerdote. “Es un día para reflexionar el sufrimiento de los niños y hacer lo posible para evitar que sufran; por eso la Iglesia hace oración por todos los niños que sufren y que son un reflejo de los Santos Inocentes en la época de Jesús”. Para finalizar, invitó a la comunidad a dedicar una oración por ellos, a pedir la intercesión de los santos niños mártires, pidiendo que todos los niños tengan una vida digna y que sus derechos sean respetados.— CLAUDIA SIERRA MEDINA

author: Rhonna Morala
title: Indian Navy Rescues U.S. Ship Crew Amid Houthi Attacks in Gulf of Aden
text:
The Indian Navy has come to the rescue of a U.S. ship crew in the Gulf of Aden following an attack by the Houthi group from Yemen.
Houthi Trade Disruptions In Backdrop
These incidents are part of a series of Houthi assaults on trade ships in the Red Sea, leading to disruptions in vital sea routes and impacting global trade, according to reports from Reuters and U.S. News.
Houthi Attack On The Genco Picardy
Late on Wednesday, the Houthi group targeted the Genco Picardy, triggering a swift response from the U.S. military, which launched strikes on 14 Houthi missiles.
Read More:
These “Trump” Stocks Could Take Off if He’s Re-elected
Many Such Attacks
This attack is just one of many in a series that the Houthis have conducted in and around the Red Sea since November.
Houthi Threat To Global Trade
The Houthi militia, known for its alignment with Iran, has been focusing its attacks on ships in the Red Sea, directly affecting trade routes connecting Asia and Europe.
Supporting Palestine
The Houthis claim to support Palestinians in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza, and they have threatened to target U.S. ships in retaliation for actions taken by the United States and the United Kingdom.
Also Read:
GOP Presidential Candidate Arrested on Federal Tax Charges
In response to the crisis, India swiftly diverted a warship already deployed in the region to rescue the 22 crew members aboard the Genco Picardy, which included nine Indians.
All Crew Members Safe
Fortunately, all crew members were reported as safe, and a fire on the vessel had been successfully extinguished. The Houthi group claimed that their missiles had scored a “direct hit” on the bulk carrier.
Disruptions In Global Trade Routes
These repeated attacks on shipping routes in the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea, accounting for approximately 15% of global shipping traffic, have far-reaching consequences for global trade.
Read More:
North Korea Fires Artillery Shells Near Border with South Korea; Leader’s Sister Mocks Seoul
Rerouting Of Vessels
Major shipping companies, such as Maersk, have been compelled to reroute vessels away from the Red Sea, opting for longer routes around Africa or temporarily suspending operations until the safety of their vessels can be guaranteed.
International Response To Houthi Attacks
On January 11, the United States and the United Kingdom launched significant strikes against Houthi targets in Yemen as a response to the ongoing Houthi attacks on crucial shipping lanes.
Clear Message To Terrorists
U.S. President Joe Biden stated that these strikes were a clear message that the U.S. would not tolerate attacks on its citizens or threats to navigation.
Also Read:
Former NRA Executive Pleads Guilty to Fraud; Agrees to Testify in New York AG Trial
Uk Prime Minister Chimes In
UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak highlighted the considerable disruption caused to a vital trade route and the resulting increase in commodity prices.
Houthi’s Continue To Strike Back
Despite international actions, the Houthi group in Yemen has affirmed its intention to continue targeting ships bound for Israel.
Impact On Oil Prices
Due to the altered shipping routes in the region, the price of oil surged by 4%. Oil tankers chose to avoid the Red Sea, leading to significant shifts in trade routes and consequently affecting the global oil market.
